message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Prazosin is an alpha-1 adrenergic blocker, which causes vasodilation, bladder sphincter relaxation, and miosis. None of the other options are correct.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Prazosin is an alpha-1 adrenergic blocker, which causes vasodilation, bladder sphincter relaxation, and miosis. It does not cause vasoconstriction or bronchial constriction, and it does not affect peristalsis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Prazosin is an alpha-blocker that causes vasodilation, bladder sphincter relaxation, and miosis. Vasoconstriction, increased peristalsis, bronchial constriction are not among the effects of this drug.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Prazosin is an alpha-blocker and it causes vasodilation, bladder sphincter relaxation, and miosis. Options A, C, and D are incorrect as they do not match the effects of prazosin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Prazosin is an alpha-1 adrenergic receptor antagonist, which means it blocks the constriction of blood vessels and leads to vasodilation. It also relaxes the bladder sphincter, leading to bladder relaxation, and causes miosis (pupillary constriction). Option A is incorrect because it lists vasoconstriction instead of vasodilation. Option C is incorrect because it lists bronchial constriction instead of relaxation, and decreased heart rate instead of no effect or slight increase. Option D is incorrect because it lists increased peristalsis instead of bladder relaxation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Prazosin is an alpha-1 adrenergic receptor blocker, which causes vasodilation and decreases blood pressure. It also causes relaxation of the bladder sphincter, leading to improved urine flow. Miosis, or constriction of the pupil, is not a known effect of prazosin. Option (A) describes the effects of alpha-1 agonists, while options (C) and (D) contain incorrect information.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Prazosin is an alpha-1 blocker, so it causes vasodilation, as well as bladder sphincter relaxation and miosis. The other options list incorrect effects of the drug.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Prazosin is an alpha-1 blocker, which causes vasodilation and therefore lowers blood pressure. It also causes relaxation of the bladder sphincter and miosis (pupillary constriction). Option A is incorrect because it suggests vasoconstriction, which is the opposite of what prazosin does. Options C and D are incorrect because they include effects that are not typically associated with alpha-1 blockers.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Prazosin blocks alpha-1 receptors, leading to vasodilation and bladder sphincter relaxation. Miosis is also a possible effect, but there is no mention of this in the question stem. None of the other options match the known effects of prazosin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Prazosin is an alpha-1 adrenergic blocker that causes vasodilation, bladder sphincter relaxation, and miosis. None of the other options include all of these effects.
